sect1.title: Description of the Disorders
sect1.para: Rates of death by suicide among individuals individuals with bipolar disorder are between 30 and 60 times that of the general population (Miller & Black, 2020 ). Of those individuals diagnosed with bipolar disorder bipolar disorder , 25–50% will attempt suicide within their lifetime (Baldessarini et al., 2006 ; Dong et al., 2020 ; Jamison, 2000 ) and 15–20% of individuals with bipolar disorder will die by suicide, with a greater risk of death in individuals that have untreated bipolar disorder (Baldessarini et al., 2006 ; Dome et al., 2019 ; Dong et al., 2020 ). Individuals with bipolar II are at a higher risk of suicide than those diagnosed with bipolar I (Plans et al., 2019 ). There are no significant differences in the prevalence of suicidal ideation between males and females with bipolar disorder (Hu et al., 2023 ), but lifetime prevalence of suicide attempts is higher in females than males (Dong et al., 2020 ; Tondo et al., 2016 ) and higher in rapid cycling bipolar disorder than non-rapid cycling bipolar disorder (Dong et al., 2020 ). Despite a higher prevalence of suicide attempts in females females , males with bipolar disorder exhibit a significantly higher prevalence of suicide-related deaths (Hu et al., 2023 ) as men with bipolar often use more lethal means of suicide (Tondo et al., 2016 ; Pompili et al., 2009 ). Several additional demographic and socioeconomic-related factors are associated with increased rates of completed suicide among people with bipolar disorder including being White, being divorced, living alone, and being under age 35 or over age 75 (Plans et al., 2019 ). Additionally, individuals who experience bipolar disorder onset at a younger age are at an increased risk of a future suicide attempt (Schaffer et al., 2015 ).

Between 20 and 30% of patients with major depressive disorder transition to bipolar disorder within 3 years. Because of this, it is imperative that clinicians are acutely aware of the possibility of this transition (Kessing et al., 2017 ; Mc Intyre et al., 2020 ). The DSM-5 Text Revision (TR) includes the following seven diagnoses under the category of Bipolar and Related Disorders: bipolar I disorder, bipolar II disorder, cyclothymic disorder, substance/medication-induced bipolar and related disorder, bipolar and related disorder due to another medical condition, other specified bipolar and related disorder, and unspecified bipolar and related disorder (American Psychiatric Association, 2022 ).

Patients experiencing mania act in ways that are uncharacteristic of their typical behavior, such as taking on an unrealistic number of work tasks or creative ventures, engaging in risky sexual behavior, or impulsively spending large amounts of money. Manic episodes must also cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or involve psychotic features or hospitalization hospitalization . Psychosis during mania may involve religious or grandiose delusions, such as that the individual is invincible or has special powers. Importantly, while bipolar I disorder is often characterized by a history of both manic and major depressive episodes, the experience of depressive episodes is not required to receive a bipolar I diagnosis. That being said, mania-only bipolar disorder is relatively rare, accounting for 5 to 28% of bipolar diagnoses based on various estimates (Perugi et al., 2007 ). To diagnose bipolar I disorder, the clinician must confirm that the manic episode is not better attributed to a schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum or other psychotic disorder (American Psychiatric Association, 2022 ).
The lifetime prevalence rate for bipolar I disorder bipolar I disorder has been estimated at approximately 1% in the United States (Clemente et al., 2015 ) and up to 2.4% globally (Merikangas et al., 2011 ). These rates are approximately equivalent between men and women (American Psychiatric Association, 2013 ; Merikangas et al., 2011 ). The mean age of onset reported in the literature ranges from 18 to 25 years old with a smaller subset of the population being diagnosed in midlife (American Psychiatric Association, 2013 ; Sentissi et al., 2019 ). Differences have been identified between these two subgroups, such that earlier age of onset is associated with greater illness severity, family history of bipolar disorder, and increased risk of suicide attempts compared to those in the older onset group (Sherazi et al., 2006 ).

sect2.title: Bipolar II Disorder
sect2.para: Bipolar II disorder Bipolar II disorder is characterized by the presence of both hypomanic episodes and major depressive episodes. Hypomanic episodes differ from manic episodes in their severity and may differ in their length as well. Specifically, hypomania is characterized by at least four consecutive days of elevated, expansive, or irritable mood along with increased activity or energy and three additional symptoms (see Table 7.1 ), or four symptoms if presenting with irritable mood only. Hypomanic episodes involve an unequivocal, uncharacteristic, and observable change in functioning in the patient, but not to the point of causing marked impairment or necessitating hospitalization. However, individuals with bipolar II disorder must have a history of at least one major depressive episode. Individuals with bipolar II disorder are more likely to present to treatment during a depressive episode versus a period of hypomania; given the lack of impairment associated with hypomania, they often do not find fault with these symptoms.

sect2.title: Cyclothymic Disorder
sect2.para: Cyclothymic disorder Cyclothymic disorder is characterized by its chronicity and subthreshold hypomanic and depressive symptoms. This disorder requires at least a two-year period in which the individual has experienced numerous periods of hypomanic symptoms that do not meet the criteria for a hypomanic episode, and numerous periods of depressive symptoms that do not constitute a major depressive episode. The time length is shortened to at least 1 year of such patterning among children and adolescents. The individual cannot be symptom-free for more than two consecutive months and symptoms must cause clinically significant distress or impairment. If an individual subsequently meets the criteria for major depressive disorder, bipolar II disorder, or bipolar I disorder, the cyclothymic disorder diagnosis is removed. The lifetime prevalence rate of cyclothymic disorder ranges from 0.4 to 2.5% (American Psychiatric Association, 2013 ; Merikangas et al., 2011 ) and is equally common among men and women women . The disorder is thought to typically emerge in adolescence and early adulthood, and has a 15–50% likelihood of subsequently converting to bipolar I or II (American Psychiatric Association, 2013 ).

sect2.title: Substance/Medication-Induced Bipolar and Related Disorder
sect2.para: Individuals who develop mood disturbances as a result of substance or medication use can receive a diagnosis of substance/medication-induced bipolar and related disorder. This condition is characterized by a prominent and persistent shift in affect that may be elevated, expansive, or irritable, and may be accompanied by increased energy or activity levels; the presence of depressed mood or anhedonia is not required to receive this diagnosis. It must be determined that the substance in question is capable of causing such mood effects and that the symptoms only emerged subsequent to the substance use.

Substances Substances that may lead to such effects include stimulants, steroids, and phencyclidine (PCP). Symptoms should not be better accounted for by a non-substance-related bipolar disorder and must cause clinically significant distress or impairment. Importantly, this diagnosis does not refer to hypomanic or manic symptoms resulting from the use of an antidepressant medication or electroconvulsive therapy. It must be confirmed that the emergence of hypomania and mania persists at a fully syndromal level beyond the physiological effects of these treatments to be considered to represent “true” bipolar disorder and does not fall under the category of being substance or medication-induced. This change is consistent with research indicating that antidepressant-induced mania or hypomania is a highly specific indicator of subsequent spontaneous manic or hypomanic episodes, and therefore a conversion to a bipolar diagnosis, among those being treated for depression (Akiskal et al., 1983 ; Ghaemi et al., 2002 ).

sect2.title: Bipolar and Related Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition
sect2.para: The diagnosis of bipolar and related disorder due to another medical condition is given when the individual displays a persistent period of elevated, expansive, or irritable mood accompanied by increased activity or energy that is thedirect physiological consequence of another medical condition. Possible medical conditions that may result in this presentation include Cushing’s disease, multiple sclerosis, stroke, and traumatic brain injuries. Symptoms occurring exclusively during periods of delirium do not qualify, nor do symptoms that predate the development of the medical condition in question.

sect2.title: Other Specified Bipolar and Related Disorder
sect2.para: A diagnosis of other specified bipolar and related disorder may be used when the full criteria for any of the abovementioned disorders have not been met but the individual is experiencing clinically significant impairment or distress. Examples of circumstances in which this diagnosis is appropriate include the presence of: (1) major depressive episodes and hypomanic episodes of less than 4 days, (2) major depressive episodes and hypomanic episodes with fewer than three symptoms, (3) hypomanic episodes and no history of major depressive episodes, and (4) symptoms of cyclothymic disorder for less than 2 years in adults or less than 1 year in children or adolescents.

sect2.title: Unspecified Bipolar and Related Disorder
sect2.para: The unspecified bipolar and related disorder diagnosis may be used in circumstances in which the individual displays symptoms of a bipolar or related disorder causing clinically significant distress or impairment but does not meet full criteria for any of the disorders discussed above. This diagnosis is often used when the clinician does not have enough information to make a more definitive diagnosis, such as after conducting a brief diagnostic screen under time constraints.

sect2.title: Specifiers
sect2.para: A variety of specifiers may be added to a diagnosis to provide further detail regarding the patient’s presentation. The “with anxious distress” specifier can be used to characterize patients with at least two symptoms of anxiety occurring during a manic, hypomanic, or depressive episode. Co-occurring anxiety is associated with greater illness severity among individuals with bipolar disorders disorders . An indication of a manic or hypomanic episode “with mixed features” refers to the presence of at least three co-occurring depressive symptoms during the episode; a depressive episode with mixed features indicates the presence of at least three concurrent hypomanic or manic symptoms. The “with rapid cycling” specifier refers to the presence of at least four episodes of hypomania, mania, or major depression occurring within the past year. Rapid cycling may be more common in women, is associated with greater illness severity, and has a high prevalence in individuals with bipolar II (Miola et al., 2023 ).

The “with melancholic features” specifier captures depressive episodes marked by a near-total loss of pleasurable feelings, while “with atypical features” refers to depressive episodes characterized by responsiveness to positive stimuli and increased appetite and sleep, among other symptoms. The “with mood-congruent psychotic features” or “with mood-incongruent psychotic features” specifier can be applied when delusions or hallucinations are present within a manic or depressive episode (American Psychiatric Association, 2022 ), and “with catatonia” can be specified when psychomotor immobility and lack of responsiveness to external stimuli are observed.

The “with peripartum onset” specifier is applied when the mood episode occurs either during pregnancy or in the first 4 weeks after delivery. The postpartum period is particularly high risk among women with bipolar disorders; they are 23–37 times more likely to have a psychiatric admission in the 30 days following birth compared to non-childbearing periods (Munk-Olsen et al., 2006 ; Sharma et al., 2017 ). Peripartum mood episodes with psychotic features occur in between 0.1 and 0.2% of deliveries and are more likely among women with histories of prior peripartum mood episodes or prior mood disorder disorder diagnoses (American Psychiatric Association, 2013 ; Perry et al., 2021 ).
